text: Yes it is
I want to do criminology, but one of my teachers said it’s hard to get a job in the future unless you specialise in it.
I’m thinking I might do criminology joint with psychology, but still not 100% sure
What did you do at university?

Since Criminology and Psychology are related, combining both would be a good idea since you are interested in these fields...and then later on you can decide where you want to specialise after having gained the knowledge and experience from studying. I did my Bachelor degree in Business Management and then decided that I was much more interested to people and how they work, so later on I did a Masters degree in Business Psychology which gave me a more of a deeper understanding in what motivates people inside businesses and how having an optimal working experience helps them be happier and more productive..But after that I also wanted to expand this in a more of an everyday context so I decided to study Life Coaching as well and specialise in motivating people achieving their goals and getting unstuck :smile:

I had a look at the personal statement and I find it very nicely written and it gives a clear idea of your interests and experience which is amazing! If I were to edit something it would be on the very last sentence I don't know if you'd consider writing something along the lines of " I believe in my strong ability to see intricate details from different perspectives (if you want to add your interest in people as well for example?)  which will aid me in studying criminology and put my skills into practice in the future"
other than that it's a great statement and your skills and experience for the age of 17 are very remarkable :+1::smiley:
(when I say your interest in people in the brackets, that's an example, I meant if you want to add any other information you find relevant but of course also use that if it represents you)

I noticed in the information you provided prospela with, that you mentioned you are finding it difficult to make the personal statement because of lack of work experience.. But I see that you do have quite some good and relevant experience so far.. is it something more and specific that the application for this degree requires?
Yes at first I was very nervous about starting a personal statement, it was very overwhelming, but once I started I got the hang of it
And yh I wanted work experience regarding young offenders or something more related to psychology/criminology
What did you do after you graduated from university, did you get the job you wanted straight away or was it a long journey to get to where you are now?

sometimes things seem overwhelming because we might project fears we have on them and make them sound difficult in our heads, but as you saw for yourself, when you start working on them they start to flow..

I did work in some environments but they weren't very fulfilling for me personally and felt like I couldn't give as much as I wanted to so I decided to start my own business.. But having worked at some roles (they were exciting but not what I had as a goal) gave me the experience to figure out what I do want to do..

before starting my own business, the last role I had was an internship at a Business Psychologist's office where I got to learn things on experience but still I personally wanted to do things my way :smile:
that's when I realised that every little step we make is leading us where we want to eventually be
and also in order for me to be able to coach people in the subjects I felt like I would benefit them, being self-employed was the best way to achieve that.. but that's because of this specific role
So, the criminology degree asks for the applicants to have experience already regarding young offenders? For a Bachelor's degree?
I am asking because in my experience, I was only asked when applying for the Master's degree to have some experience

Also, I noticed that you mention you are a great listener in the prospela form, I would encourage you to include that in your application because it is a great and useful skill to have when relating with psychology

I also like the fact that you included in the statement about the book you are reading on the teenage brain as this really shows your desire to get to know how people work - also a great aspect for psychology/criminology
so this also counts as related to the subject..
Thank you:relaxed:

It’s actually not necessary for me to have experience regarding young offenders, but I thought it would be good to have experience in something I’m doing a degree for, so I have deeper understanding of the subject

I understand that..but on the other hand you are only 17 and you will get to have experience through your degree and assignments during the course and also I guess through the university itself because there's usually a lot of supports to students to practice what they're learning... and they help in terms of finding work experience through the university
support**
I think at this point in time, the skills and experience you have make you a great candidate for a criminology/psychology degree :smile:
Ok, thank you soo much!!:relaxed:
I have a quick question
I’ve been considering taking a gap year after year 13, do you think it’s a good idea?
Is there any particular reason you are thinking to take a gap year then? Do you have something in mind?

Well I’m moving to a different city after sixth form, so I want to spend the year helping out with the new house, exploring the new city, focusing a bit on myself since I’ve prioritised school work a lot, travel,  I also want to get a job to earn some money and have some money saved up.
